title: How to Make Farina

steps.headline: Procure a grain mill with a hand grinder.
steps.description: A grain mill with a hand grinder will help you achieve the desired consistency for your farina, while an electric grinder can quickly turn your wheat berries into flour. You can choose a hand grinder specifically designed for farina, or use any grain mill you have on hand. Check a kitchen specialty store to find a grain mill with a hand grinder. You could also use a coffee grinder or a food processor if you don’t have access to a grain mill.

steps.headline: Select wheat berries.
steps.description: You can choose from hard or soft, wheat or white wheat berries. Soft wheat berries have a less grainy texture than hard wheat berries. White wheat berries have a lighter color and texture, although they contain the same nutrients as wheat berries. Health food stores carry wheat berries, and you can also purchase them online.

steps.headline: Grind 3 to 4 cups (376 to 502 g) of wheat berries in your hand grinder.
steps.description: Put a small amount of wheat berries in the top opening of the grain mill and turn the crank to grind them. Repeat until all your berries have been run through the grain mill. One run through the grinder should be enough to break the wheat berries up into farina -- you don’t want to grind them so finely that you end up with flour.

steps.headline: Store your farina in airtight containers.
steps.description: You should only grind as much farina as you plan to use within a few days, as it goes bad quickly since it doesn’t contain preservatives. Store your farina in airtight containers, like glass jars, at room temperature.

steps.headline: Freeze your unused farina.
steps.description: If you make more farina than you can use in a few days, you can freeze the excess. Put it in a sealed container and pop it in the freezer for up to 30 days.

steps.headline: Boil water and salt in a saucepan.
steps.description: Put 3 cups (710 mL) of water in a small saucepan or pot and add ½ teaspoon (7.5 g) of salt. Place the pan or pot on a small stovetop burner and bring it to a boil. You can substitute the water for milk if you desire a creamier farina.

steps.headline: Add the farina and reduce heat.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (180 g) farina to the water and stir to combine. Reduce the heat to low.

steps.headline: Stir constantly while heating the farina for 10 minutes.
steps.description: To keep your farina from getting lumpy, stir it constantly. Cook the farina for 10 minutes over low heat.

steps.headline: Add any desired toppings and serve.
steps.description: You can add a splash of cream or milk, or a little brown sugar or honey to your farina, or top it with cinnamon, raisins, or berries. Then, serve your farina for a delicious and nutritional breakfast porridge.

steps.headline: Boil the sugar and water for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (192 g) of sugar and 1/2 cup (118 g) of water to a medium saucepan or pot and stir to combine. Place the pan or pot on a stovetop burner and heat on medium-high until the mixture becomes syrupy, which takes around 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Add butter and cooked farina to the pot.
steps.description: Add 1/4 cup (58 g) of butter and 3 cups (539 g) of cooked farina to the pot. Stir the mixture thoroughly until it is completely blended. It will be thick.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into a dish and add honey and walnuts.
steps.description: Transfer the mixture to a dish, then top it with 1/2 cup (118 mL) of honey and 1/2 cup (58 g) of chopped walnuts. Serve the dish and enjoy!
